byline.contributor: Paula Moura contributed reporting from São Paulo, Vinod Sreeharsha from Rio de Janeiro, and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from New York

abstract: Brazilian researchers report mosquito-borne virus known as Zika is responsible for rapid surge in babies born with microcephaly, rare incurable condition in which their heads are abnormally small; nation has marked 2,782 cases in 2015, compared with 147 in 2014; many pregnant women in country are in state of panic; some scientists say more research is necessary before link with Zika can be established.
lead_paragraph: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, suspected of fueling a spike in microcephaly, is at the core of one of the most alarming Brazilian health crises in decades.

headline.main: Alarm Spreads in Brazil Over a Virus and a Surge in Malformed Infants
headline.print_headline: Mosquito-Borne Peril to Babies Unsettles Brazil

snippet: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, suspected of fueling a spike in microcephaly, is at the core of one of the most alarming Brazilian health crises in decades.
